title: Netflix hints at working on mobile-friendly content
title_page: Netflix hints at working on mobile-friendly content | Daily Mail Online
text:
Good things come in small packages - including original TV series.
Netflix may soon be re-cutting its original shows and films so they work on even the smallest of screens.
The company has hinted that it could be modifying content to satisfy its growing audience of mobile streamers.
Scroll down for video
The TV-streaming company is behind hit shows such as The Crown and House Of Cards (pictured) might be about to make special mobile-friendly versions of their series
THE SMALL SCREEN Netflix chiefs are thinking about making mobile-friendly versions of their series. Tweaking content means even subscribers who watch on the small screen could get an immersive viewing experience. Certain shots which work on the big screen at the moment might be hard to see on a smaller screen. This might give the entertainment company an edge over key rivals such as Amazon and Hulu who do not currently offer their subscribers this service.
In a press briefing in San Francisco on Wednesday, Neil Hunt, chief product officer at Netflix revealed that the entertainment company is thinking about making mobile-friendly versions of their series.
Tweaking content means even subscribers who watch on the small screen could get an immersive viewing experience.
The TV-streaming company is behind hit shows such as The Crown and House Of Cards.
Certain shots which work on the big screen at the moment might be hard to see or seem pinched when watched on a smartphone.
'It's not inconceivable that you could take a master [copy] and make a different cut for mobile,' said Mr Hunt in the speech, according to The Verge.
'To date, Netflix hasn't been delivering different cuts for different viewing platforms, Hunt said, but it's something we will explore over the next few years', he said.
This might give the entertainment company an edge over key rivals such as Amazon and Hulu who do not currently offer their subscribers this service.
In an increasingly competitive market it is important to stay ahead of the mark - especially with companies such as Snapchat and Apple rumoured to be thinking about original programming.
Earlier this month, Netflix announced it is working on ways to give viewers control of key plot decisions.
Certain shots which work on the big screen at the moment might be hard to see on a smaller screen. This might give the American entertainment company an edge over key rivals such as Amazon and Hulu (stock image)
Some of the storylines will be simple and linear, like the Choose Your Own Adventure books many grew up with.
For example, viewers might decide whether an inmate in the prison drama Orange Is The New Black joins a gang or not.
The technology could also potentially be used to allow Princess Margaret to marry Peter Townsend in The Crown, instead of having her relationship with the divorcee blocked by the Establishment.
Other storylines will be much more complex, allowing viewers to connect plot points in a variety of ways using their TV remotes.
